Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Development of Atom Efficient Single Site Catalysts for Low Temperature Hydrocarbon and CO Emissions Removal

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
The project marries computational advances in "single site" catalysis with the demands of automotive catalysis to provide theory-driven aid to experimental design of low-temperature active and thermally stable next-generation automotive catalysts. This is an ambitious undertaking given the complex reaction environment of automotive catalysts and the broad range of conditions that they experience over their useful life. The proposed research will aid the implementation of high-efficiency low-temperature combustion systems by enabling the design of catalysts capable of meeting strict emission standards in a low-temperature exhaust environment, while also minimizing reliance on expensive noble metals. Development of automotive catalysts has historically relied on trial-and-error catalyst screening, with little theoretical underpinning. This proposal has the potential to develop a theory-aided approach to catalyst design, thereby opening up the design space while reducing the experimental burden.

The proposal lays groundwork for a comprehensive, predictive, and experimentally validated model of single site catalysis for low-temperature automotive emission oxidation of carbon monoxide and hydrocarbons. It builds on recent advances in catalysis that speak to the ability to synthesize single site catalysts and demonstrate their advantages over supported metal clusters or particles in a number of reactions. The extension of these advances to automotive catalysis is not straight-forward, however. Automotive catalysis is more complicated than most catalytic applications because of the complex and dynamic changes in exhaust gas environment and broad operating temperature ranges under which the catalysts must function over a long life. The proposal will build on experimental progress in the synthesis of single site palladium-containing catalysts, as well as previous work demonstrating the effectiveness of lanthana for stabilizing noble metal particles. The dual thrust to predict single site catalyst properties needed for both low-temperature conversion efficiency and durability at high temperatures represents an ambitious extension of computational efforts over previous work. The resulting methods and understanding should be generalizable to other systems. The investigator has also included in the proposal plans to integrate computational catalysis into an educational program for high school students aimed at illustrating the importance of fundamental chemistry for advances in alternative energy fields. Those programs will be conducted in collaboration with educational institutions and existing programs that aim to provide opportunities for minorities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project married computational advances in "single-site" catalysis with the demands of automotive catalysis to provide theory-driven aid to experimental design of low-temperature active and thermally stable next-generation automotive catalysts. The proposed research aided in the implementation of high-efficiency low-temperature combustion systems by enabling the design of catalysts capable of meeting strict emission standards in a low-temperature exhaust environment, while also minimizing reliance on expensive noble metals. The development of automotive catalysts has historically relied on trial-and-error catalyst screening, with little theoretical underpinning. During the course of this project, a theory-aided approach to catalyst design was developed, thereby opening up the design space while reducing the experimental burden. 

 

By combining state-of-the-art approaches in experimental and theoretical catalysis research, the catalyst under investigation was characterized and the factors that influence its reactivity were determined. In particular, first principles-based calculations were used to model the electronic properties of single-site platinum atoms that are deposited over a copper surface oxide support. This electronic information allowed us to simulate scanning tunneling microscope images and to compare them to the experimental images as measured in the Sykes group at Tufts. Any other experimentally-available spectroscopic information was also compared to the computational simulations so as to develop a realistic model of the catalyst under low-temperature operating conditions. In this way, the platinum sites that are responsible for the observed low-temperature oxidation of carbon monoxide were identified as well as the factors that influence their selectivity. Other single-site catalysts composed of iridium and lanthanum were also modeled and compared to the experimental results of the Wang group at Washington State University since such a catalyst was determined to be a promising heterogeneous catalyst replacement of the homogenous analog for the production of acetic acid.

 

The findings of this study resulted in four important outcomes regarding the performance of single-site platinum catalyst when deposited on a copper surface oxide support. First, the complete oxidation cycle for carbon monoxide was determined. These results show that the most difficult step in the catalytic cycle is the oxidation of the first carbon monoxide molecule that interacts with the surface. The calculations suggest that these single-site platinum atoms could perform the complete carbon monoxide oxidation cycle if a proper stabilization method could be found, which would prevent the platinum from deactivating once the first carbon dioxide molecule is formed. Second, the potential for hydrogen activation, the breaking of the first carbon-hydrogen bond in methane, and water activation was determined. For hydrogen activation, molecular hydrogen was found to not adsorb onto the copper surface oxide and only weakly binds to the oxide supported platinum atom. Such results suggest that this catalyst is inactive toward hydrogen oxidation, making this system a good candidate as a carbon monoxide preferential oxidation catalyst. The calculations further suggest that such a catalyst is inactive for methane activation, while the presence of platinum facilitates the activation of water. Third, the structure of two well-defined surface defects and the mechanism by which they activate methanol was determined. Fourth, the interactions of water with the surface oxide was characterized and the growth of an ice layer on said surface was modeled.

 

As for our investigation involving iridium and lanthanum as a potential heterogeneous single-site catalyst for the production of acetic acid, two important outcomes resulted from our work. First, the methanol carbonylation mechanism was determined. Second, the role of lanthanum during the carbonylation reaction mechanism was elucidated.

 

Through several conference presentations, this project had a significant number of broader impacts in the scientific community. Further, our work was performed in close collaboration with experiment. Such an approach is needed if one wants to truly understand how and why a catalyst works, which can then be used in other chemical reaction studies. This project has engaged one graduate student and two postdoctoral researchers. Outreach activities for K-12 students were developed so as to educate them about how catalysis impacts their daily lives, and specifically how emission catalysis is important to protect the environment and human health. During this project period, this activity was delivered to a high school classroom (~20 students) on a Native American reserve.
